content: The "Veterans Education Enhancement Act of 2016" allows entitlement for certain licensure and certification tests under the Department of Veterans Affairs Post-9/11 Educational Assistance Program. The "Veterans Education Enhancement Act of 2016" allows entitlement for certain licensure and certification tests under the Department of Veterans Affairs Post-9/11 Educational Assistance Program. The Act amends sections related to licensure and certification tests, national tests, and effective dates for test-taking. The "Veterans Education Enhancement Act of 2016" extends the percentage increase in rates payable under Department of Veterans Affairs educational assistance programs until fiscal year 2025. It also extends the authority for the Veterans' Advisory Committee on Education until December 31, 2021, and includes provisions for training school certifying officials. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, in consultation with State approving agencies, sets training requirements for school certifying officials at educational institutions with 20 or more individuals using educational assistance under title 38, United States Code. Failure to meet these requirements may result in disapproval of courses offered by the institution. The curr_chunk states that a school certifying official is an employee responsible for certifying veteran enrollment at an educational institution. The term "State approving agency" refers to a department or agency designated by a State under title 38, United States Code. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF HOUSING STIPEND PAYMENTS FOR REDUCTION OF COURSE HOURS. The amendment to section 3313 of title 38, United States Code, specifies the determination of housing stipend payments based on basic allowances for housing rates. It also outlines a reduction in housing stipend payments for individuals who drop course hours during an academic period. The amendment allows the Secretary to reduce housing stipend payments on a pro rata basis for individuals who receive an overpayment due to a reduction in course hours. Effective August 1, 2017. SEC. 7. LIMITATION ON USE OF REPORTING FEES PAYABLE TO EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS AND JOINT APPRENTICESHIP TRAINING COMMITTEES. Section 3684(c) of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to pay educational institutions or apprenticeship program sponsors a reporting fee in lieu of other compensation for required reports. The fee is calculated based on the number of eligible veterans or persons enrolled in education or training programs under specific chapters of the title. The reporting fee is paid to educational institutions or apprenticeship training committees for temporary custody and delivery of required reports. The fee is calculated based on the number of eligible veterans or persons enrolled in education or training programs. No reporting fee can be offset by the Secretary against any liability of the institution unless uncontested or upheld by a court decree. The reporting fee paid to educational institutions or apprenticeship training committees is used solely for certifications required under specific chapters or for supporting programs for veterans. For institutions with 75 or more enrollees, the fee cannot be merged with general funds and must be paid from appropriated readjustment benefits.
